0.00.text:
Translator: Helena Bowen
Reviewer: Denise RQ

16.13.text: I try to keep the fact

18.01.text:
that I've written
a parenting book a secret.

22.38.text: I live in a small town,

23.93.text:
and when people see me coming
in the grocery store,

26.35.text: I see a look of panic in their eyes.

29.42.text:
I assume they think
I'm going to judge them

31.60.text:
because they're locked in
a power struggle over buying Fruit Loops,

36.81.text:
I am likely just off the heels of a battle
with my own kids,

41.19.text:
and I'm using this trip
to the grocery store as an excuse

44.58.text: to get the hell out of my house.

48.99.text:
Safe to say that none of this
will help me get my next book deal

54.60.text:
but in addition to having written
a parenting book,

57.60.text:
my work is based in
the science of mindfulness.

61.28.text:
So, not only is there this illusion
that I know everything about parenting

66.14.text:
but I'm supposed to be
doing it all blissfully.

74.46.text:
disciplining and encouraging my kids
in my best yogi voice.

80.88.text:
But most days, come five o'clock,
I'm far more tempted

84.58.text:
to reach for the Chardonnay
than the meditation cushion.

89.69.text:
You see, my generation is slowly
but surely losing [its mind].

98.38.text:
Generation X was identified as
the most stressed generation in America.

103.63.text:
To complicate things, many of us
GenXers decided to have kids.

109.98.text:
This created what I call
'Generation Stress',

114.14.text:
a generation of stressed out parents,
raising a generation of stressed out kids.

121.40.text:
My daughter started sixth grade
about a month ago,

123.91.text:
and she was so excited
to start middle school.

126.89.text: She shared with me these Pinterest photos,

129.15.text:
explaining what all
the sixth graders are doing.

138.21.text:
This is what happens
when Generation Stress procreates.

147.13.text:
It seems as though we figured out a way
to make entering middle school

150.93.text:
even more anxiety-provoking
than it already was

157.29.text:
to the must-have
back to school supply list.

162.70.text:
So we have this generation
of over-achieving, over-stimulated,

167.06.text:
over-connected parents
raising the same types of kids.

173.50.text:
We have big stressors:
we have financial difficulties,

176.81.text:
demanding careers, divorce,
health problems, school violence,

180.32.text:
teen suicides, and record-high rates
of anxiety and depression

190.45.text:
traffic jams, 24/7 texts and emails
from our coworkers,

195.25.text:
juggling whose turn it is
to stay home with the sick kid.

199.06.text:
Our kids not only absorb our stress,
but they have their own triggers,

203.60.text:
trying to keep up with
growing piles of homework

206.08.text:
while staying on top
of the latest thread on Instagram,

209.19.text: and signing up for one more honors class

211.20.text:
to improve their shot
at getting into college.

214.96.text:
Before we dismiss
the little stuff as no big deal,

218.76.text: think about this for a moment:

221.08.text:
When we compare
the brain scans of Vietnam vets

224.85.text:
with the brain scans
of chronically stressed out people,

228.95.text: they actually have a lot in common.

232.50.text:
The compound effects
of life's little annoyances add up

236.40.text: and can be as detrimental as true PTSD.

240.64.text:
We respond to these stressors,
big and little,

243.70.text:
by constantly stimulating
the survival mechanisms in our brains,

248.79.text:
and so our bodies respond,
again and again.

252.64.text: Our hearts race, our blood pressure rises,

255.07.text:
our decision-making centers
in our brains stay roped off,

258.14.text:
while our bodies and our brains
tend to what we perceive

270.41.text:
So, if you're about to fake
a bathroom break

272.58.text:
to escape what has thus far
not been the most playful talk, sit tight.

278.99.text:
In the same way that all of this crap,
for lack of a better word,

283.79.text:
puts us into survival mode,
simple practices can get us out.

292.58.text:
to some pretty extreme lengths
to create change.

295.58.text:
We'll work 80 hours a week
to get that promotion,

298.15.text:
hire a personal trainer
to help us lose 10 pounds,

302.79.text:
botoxing our foreheads
and plumping our lips,

306.56.text:
and every parent I know
will move heaven and earth

312.09.text:
We'll shoe-horn in
one more essential activity,

314.74.text: remove all the gluten from our households,

317.20.text:
and hire a private coach to give our kids
the edge at soccer try-outs.

324.92.text:
is more elemental
and infinitely more important.

329.40.text:
I'm talking about emotional
and physical health,

336.92.text:
With all this at stake, can any of us
afford not to unplug a little,

341.97.text:
look each other in the eye,
and integrate a few simple practices

347.00.text:
to calm the survival
mechanisms in the brain

349.88.text:
and buoy us all from this generation
of stress we have created.

356.54.text: Research tells us that lasting change

359.68.text:
doesn't come from
drastic life transformations.

363.21.text:
It comes from a collection
of small changes,

366.99.text:
changes that don't require money,
leaving the city, or quitting your job.

372.45.text:
Short, simple practices
can get us out of survival mode

377.09.text: and shift us from surviving to thriving.

380.70.text:
Today, I'd like to share
a few of my favorite practices.

385.70.text:
I have a friend, Erin, who's a teacher
who's had a really difficult year.

392.40.text:
On October 11th, she finished
her final day of work

395.67.text:
prior to her scheduled c-section
the next Monday.

400.05.text:
Her colleagues had thrown her
a baby shower,

402.66.text:
her parents and in-laws
had flown in town for the birth.

406.98.text:
On Sunday, the day before
the scheduled procedure,

410.68.text: Erin gave birth to a still-born child.

414.95.text:
She went from anticipating one
of the most exciting life-changing events

420.87.text:
to trying to figure out
how she was going to explain

423.44.text:
to a group of second graders
why she was back at work so soon.

428.65.text:
Days can be brutally hard
for my friend Erin,

431.34.text:
but she's convinced that life
is made to be lived,

434.88.text:
and she started this little practice
with two of her colleagues.

438.89.text: At the end of each school day,

440.36.text:
they text each other
three good things about their day.

444.09.text: Sometimes it's that the sun is shining,

446.01.text:
sometimes it's that a student
who was struggling did well on a test.

449.68.text:
Regardless, this simple practice
that takes about 60 seconds to do

454.15.text:
profoundly impacted how they felt
about their days and their lives.

459.39.text:
They enjoyed work more, they were
less exhausted at the end of the week,

466.67.text:
Research from Duke University
supports what they're doing.

471.72.text:
this practice of recognizing
our positive experiences for two weeks

476.33.text:
significantly lowers depression
and burn-out, increases happiness,

480.36.text:
improves sleep, and helps us create
a better work-life balance.

484.76.text:
When they followed
participants in this study

487.18.text:
for six months
after the two-week practice,

490.14.text:
they found this practice
trends better than Prozac

492.84.text:
for easing depression
and boosting happiness.

496.88.text:
When I talked to my friend Erin
about this practice, she said this,

502.11.text:
"It would be so easy for me to spend
every day dwelling on what I do not have.

507.52.text: Finding the good forces me to become aware

510.60.text:
of the multiple opportunities
of good in my day.

514.44.text: This is the gift born out of my loss,

517.45.text:
the good that reshapes
my mind and spirit."

522.14.text: I come from a long line of perfectionists.

525.45.text:
My grandfather was a perfectionist,
my dad was a perfectionist,

530.88.text:
though, I like to consider myself
a recovering perfectionist.

535.12.text:
Our society is filled with perfectionists,
and it sounds pretty cool to be one,

539.11.text:
but true perfectionism
doesn't propel anyone forward,

542.69.text:
and it has actually been shown
to hold us back,

545.29.text:
and can lead to crippling anxiety,
depression, and even suicide.

550.93.text:
I once had someone tell me
I was doing mindfulness wrong.

559.21.text: Now, it sounds like you know

562.13.text:
that mindfulness is a practice
based in non-judgmental awareness

568.71.text:
yet here I was, being judged,
and judged pretty critically.

572.30.text:
I honestly thought I was going to be
turned in to the mindfulness police

575.72.text:
for allowing 6-year-olds
to use a prop while meditating.

582.71.text: This woman's comment sent me reeling.

585.43.text:
The perfectionist in me determined
that I should close up shop,

588.75.text:
crawl into a hole,
and figure out a new career.

592.05.text: It took mere seconds for me

593.85.text:
to disregard years of education
and experience training kids and adults,

598.70.text:
all the research
that backed up my methods,

601.00.text:
and all the beautiful stories
that I had been told

603.35.text: about how my work had helped people.

605.10.text: I immediately went down this rabbit hole

607.46.text:
of "I'm totally worthless
because this woman said so."

611.14.text:
Perfectionist or not, we in
Generation Stress beat up ourselves.

617.21.text:
Unless we learn to acknowledge
and reframe our mistakes,

623.42.text: When I talked to my dad about the fact

625.27.text:
that part of what I would be
speaking about today was perfectionism,

628.46.text:
he said this, "There is nothing wrong
with attempting perfection,

633.57.text:
so long as you understand
that success is remote.

637.66.text: Failure should not be viewed negatively,

640.03.text:
but rather it can serve as the basis
for future challenges,

644.15.text:
and challenge is a stimulus for
a productive, happy, and meaningful life."

650.67.text: My perfectionist dad kind of nailed it.

655.38.text:
The practice is to reframe our mistakes
and our challenges in terms of growth.

660.82.text:
When we can do this, our brain
responds to these challenges differently.

664.75.text:
They no longer send us
into a panicked downward spiral.

669.50.text:
You can reinforce this practice
by asking your parents, your grandparents,

673.44.text:
or someone you look up to about
a mistake they made that lead to growth,

677.45.text:
or share one of your own challenges
with your teen or young child.

684.67.text:
picking ourselves up
and dusting ourselves off

687.34.text: are keys to grit and resilience,

689.99.text:
resilience to all the stress
I just mentioned.

695.69.text:
Kindness shifts us
from surviving to thriving.

700.23.text:
Studies show that engaging in one act
of kindness a day for just ten days

706.51.text: and witnessing an act of kindness

708.67.text:
is almost as effective
as engaging in the act yourself,

713.29.text: as this releases serotonin in our brain,

716.02.text:
and can lead to what neuroscientists
call a peak experience,

719.41.text:
those rare moments of inspiration
that leave us grateful to be alive.

723.99.text:
These moments
don't have to be over the top.

726.10.text: You can hold the door for someone,

727.84.text:
let somebody who appears rushed
go ahead of you in line,

730.98.text:
or write a kind note to a friend
or co-worker in need.

734.93.text:
The key is to bring mindful attention
to these simple acts.

739.94.text:
I wanted to find a way to cultivate
kindness in my own family,

743.02.text: so we play a game called Rose, Bud, Thorn.

747.14.text:
that can be played at the dinner table,
on a car ride, or before going to bed,

750.94.text:
and it reinforces each of the practices
that I've talked about today.

755.46.text:
Each person takes a turn
describing their rose,

758.64.text: a good experience they had today,

760.82.text:
their thorn, a mistake
they learned from today,

764.48.text:
and their bud, an act of kindness
that they witnessed or initiated.

769.75.text:
This simple game
that takes about five minutes

772.47.text:
never ceases to shift my family
from surviving to thriving.

779.21.text:
Here's what's weird:
there was a time in my life

782.98.text:
when I would seek out
stressful situations.

786.31.text:
I took a job one summer in college
working for a bungee jumping company.

792.21.text:
I had the esteemed job
of testing the ropes.

798.00.text:
Every morning,
before any customers jumped,

800.99.text:
I would fling myself out of a basket
350 feet above the earth,

806.11.text:
and hope that my college buddies
had secured the lines.

811.95.text:
I think I got paid eight dollars an hour
for this prestigious position.

818.60.text:
Today, I don't have to pursue
extreme sports to find stress.

823.85.text: Modern living is an extreme sport.

827.49.text:
The thought of my inbox
on Monday mornings gets my heart racing,

832.04.text:
and the locker chandeliers,
those put me over the edge.

838.72.text: My point to you here is this:

841.97.text:
we are surrounded
by big and little stressors,

848.00.text:
but we don't have to embark
on major life transformations

854.72.text:
If there's one thing I hope
you remember from this talk today,

859.31.text: it is the simple practices that lead

862.45.text:
to the most significant
and sustainable changes.

867.12.text:
My life is still crazy,
but in the last 10 years

871.60.text:
that I've been teaching
and practicing mindfulness,

880.09.text:
and those moments when my kids
take my hand in theirs.

884.43.text:
I look for growth in difficult times,
even if I have to cry into a pillow first,

890.42.text:
and I take advantage
of opportunities for kindness.

898.40.text:
that shift my survival brain
to my thriving brain,

902.68.text: and leave me feeling pretty damn grateful

906.01.text:
for my hectic, overwhelming,
and imperfect life.
